chapter.htmlHeader: How common is it?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• Domestic violence and abuse is common.
    • According to the Crime Survey of England and Wales data for the year ending March 2017 [Office for National Statistics, 2017]:
      • About 1.9 million adults (1.2 million women and 713,000 men) aged 16–59 years experienced domestic abuse in the last year, equating to a prevalence of approximately 6 in 100 adults.
      • Police recorded over 1 million domestic abuse-related incidents and crimes of which 46% were recorded as domestic abuse-related crimes, which accounted for 32% of violent crimes.
    • It is estimated that at least 29.9% of women and 17% of men in England and Wales have experienced domestic violence and abuse at some point in their lives, although these figures are likely to be an underestimate as all types of domestic violence and abuse are under-recognized and under-reported [NICE, 2014].
    • Lesbian and bisexual women experience domestic violence and abuse at a similar rate to women in general, although about 33% of cases are associated with male perpetrators. About 49% of gay and bisexual men have experienced at least one incident of domestic violence and abuse since the age of 16 years compared with 17% of men in general. This includes domestic violence and abuse within same-sex relationships [NICE, 2014]. 
  • Both men and women may perpetrate or experience domestic violence and abuse. However:
    • It is more commonly inflicted on women by men, especially severe and repeated violence and sexual assault [NICE, 2014]. In a study based on reports to police, only 5% of cases involved female perpetrators in heterosexual relationships [DH, 2017].
    • Men are less likely to report abuse to the police, and are more likely to say this is because they consider it too trivial or not worth reporting [NICE, 2014].
  • Partner abuse is the most prevalent form of domestic violence and abuse among adults [NICE, 2014].
    • At least 26.6% of women and 14% of men have, at some point, experienced partner abuse since they were 16 years of age, and the prevalence is consistently higher among people in healthcare settings.
    • Each year since 1995, around 50% of all women aged 16 years or older who were murdered in England and Wales were killed by their partner or ex-partner, and around 12% of men who were murdered were killed by their partner or ex-partner.
  • Partner abuse is also prevalent in young people's relationships.
    • In the UK in 2009 [NICE, 2014]:
      • Emotional violence in an intimate partner relationship was reported by 72% of girls and 51% of boys aged 13–16 years.
      • Sexual violence was reported by 31% of girls and 16% of boys.
      • Physical violence was reported by 25% of girls and 18% of boys.
      • 1 in 6 girls reported some form of severe domestic violence and abuse inflicted on them by a partner.
    • As with adults [NICE, 2014]:
      • Girls described more abuse, more severe abuse, more direct intimidation and control, and more negative impact on their lives.
      • Young people in same-sex relationships were at greater risk than those in heterosexual relationships.
  • Domestic violence and abuse in which a parent is abused with children in the household is the most frequently reported form of trauma for children [NICE, 2014].
    • In the UK, 24.8% of people aged 18–24 years reported that they were exposed to domestic violence and abuse during their childhood.
  • Abuse of older people is common.
    • Over 250,000 older people (aged 66 and older) living in private households in England reported experiencing maltreatment (including neglect and psychological, physical, sexual, and financial abuse) from a partner (51%), another family member (49%), a close friend (5%), and a care worker (13%) [O'Keeffe, 2007; NICE, 2014].
    • Women were more likely to experience maltreatment than men (3.8% of women and 1.1% of men in the past year), and men were more often the perpetrators [O'Keeffe, 2007; NICE, 2014].
  • Abuse of parents by their children (aged 16 years and older) is under-reported (similar to other forms of domestic violence and abuse) as parents are particularly reluctant to disclose or report violence from their child [Home Office, 2015].
    • It is more commonly experienced by mothers than fathers and is more common among single parents [NICE, 2014].
  • The prevalence of 'honour'-based violence and forced marriage is difficult to estimate as incidences are under-reported [NICE, 2014]:
    • It is estimated that between 5000–8000 cases of forced marriage were reported to local and national organizations in England in 2008. In 41% of cases reported to local organizations, the person forced to marry was younger than 18 years of age.
    • 'Honour'-based violence and forced marriage both involve wider family members and can affect both men and women.
